GfxConstants Class Reference

    Radius of earth in meters.
Multiplicative scalefactors (distance).
Multiplicative constants to convert between distances in meters and MC2-scale.

In the MC2-scale the circumference at the equator is 2^32.

  • const float64 MC2SCALE_TO_METER
    From MC2-scale to meter.
  • const float64 MC2SCALE_TO_CENTIMETER
    From MC2-scale to centimeter (float).
  • const int32 MC2SCALE_TO_CENTIMETER_INT32
    From MC2-scale to centimeter (integer).
  • const float64 SQUARE_MC2SCALE_TO_SQUARE_METER
    From (MC2-scale)^2 to (meter)^2.
  • const float64 METER_TO_MC2SCALE
    From meter to MC2-scale.
  • const float64 SQUARE_METER_TO_SQUARE_MC2SCALE
    From (meter)^2 to (MC2-scale)^2.
Multiplicative scalefactors (position).
Multiplicative scalefactors used to convert from degrees, minutes, seconds and sweref93_lla to "our" unit.

The factors are calculated as:
degreeFactor = (PI / 180.0) * ((float64) pow(2,32)/(2*PI)) = (1/360)*2^32 = 2^32/(360) = 11930464.7111
minuteFactor = degreeFactor/60 = 198841.078518
secondFactor = degreeFactor/3600 = 3314.01797531
radianFactor = degreeFactor * 180 / M_PI
sweref93LLAFactor = ( ((float64) MAX_UINT32) / (2.0 * M_PI))

  • const double degreeFactor
    From degrees to our unit.
  • const double invDegreeFactor
    From our unit to degrees.
  • const double minuteFactor
    From minutes to our unit.
  • const double secondFactor
    From seconds to our unit.
  • const double radianFactor
    From radians to out unit.
  • const double invRadianFactor
    From our unit to radians.
  • const double sweref93LLAFactor
    From sweref93 lla to our unit.
Multiplicative factors, degrees <-> radians.
Multiplicative factors for degrees <-> radians.

The factors are calculated as:
degreeToRadianFactor = ( PI / 180 )
radianTodegreeFactor = ( 180 / PI )


  • const double degreeToRadianFactor
    From degrees to radians.
  • const double radianTodegreeFactor
    From radians to degrees.

const int32 GfxConstants::IMPOSSIBLE [static]
 

An impossible value for coordinates.

This value is impossible for LATITUDE but not for LONGITUDE. The reason for being impossible is that it is situated beyond the poles.
